thread.title: Tax reform commission idea gains support
thread.title_full: Tax reform commission idea gains support | afr.com

author: Joanna Mather
title: Tax reform commission idea gains support
text:
There is growing support for an Australian Tax Reform Commission. by Joanna Mather Wanted: an eminent person with the wits and wherewithal to cut through politics and self-interest in order to come up with a decade-long tax plan for Australia.
That's how the job advertisement might read if accounting firm EY is successful in its push to establish an independent tax reform commission.
EY tax policy leader Alf Capito envisages a tax reform body similar to the productivity and law reform commissions.
He says the governor-general could be given responsibility for appointing a chairperson and commissioners for periods of up to five years.
Although the commission would report to parliament and provide advice to government, it would still be up to the elected representatives of the day to legislate tax policy.
"The Australian public has lost confidence in the highly politicised tax reform process and is crying out for an institution tasked with leading the reform debate," Mr Capito said.
He's not alone in calling for a tax reform commission.
Former Liberal leader John Hewson has long called for a "fiercely independent" tax commission.
 BHP Billiton chief executive Andrew McKenzie has also spoken in favour of such a body.
The Business Council of Australia told the government's tax review: "Serious consideration should be given to the establishment of an independent advisory body, such as a Tax Reform Commission, to help steward tax reform over the next decade and to reduce the risk of policy reversals we cannot afford."
Chartered Accountants Australia and New Zealand support "an expert organisation which can look beyond the election cycle and recommend, design, develop and implement change, based on an over-arching strategy set by the government".
But PwC tax partner Paul Abbey rejected the idea as "cowardice".
"Governments have to take on the issue and deal with it," he said.
"When we've gotten big things done in this country, governments have done them and explained why they've needed to be done.
"You can look at NSW and point to the fact that governments are privatising assets because they explained it and they got it done.
"The nsw government is effectively leading the tax debate because they're prepared to explain what they want and get it done."
Mr Capito analysed the tax policy processes adopted by countries with broadly similar political systems to come up with a model for the Australian Tax Reform Commission.
He concluded that it should be an independent statutory body with a defined role to conduct strategic reviews of the tax system, develop advice on specific initiatives and review policy implementation.
"There is a growing groundswell of support for this proposal," Mr Capito said, adding that his preference was to morph the existing Board of Taxation into a new reform commission.
The board is a non-statutory advisory body tasked with contributing business and community perspectives on tax for the treasurer.
